title-group.article-title: Cumulation of Effects in Calculating the Deterioration of Fatigue Loaded Structures

article-meta.aff: Faculty of Mechanical and Mechatronics Engineering, Process Equipment Department, POLITEHNICA University Bucharest, Bucharest 060042, Romania

author-notes.corresp: *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. E-mail: vvjinescu@yahoo.com

abstract.p: It has been introduced and analyzed on literature-based relations that calculating the deterioration produced by cyclic loading with normal stresses can be actually calculated. Based on the principle of critical energy, deterioration has been expressed as a power function. The deteriorations thus calculated can be summed up in order to obtain the cumulated effect of the external loadings. There have been established expressions for the deterioration produced by the action of: a single cyclic stress, several blocks of cyclic stresses with normal and/or shear stresses by taking into consideration the cumulated effect of vibrations and/or corrosion, cracked or crack free structures. The relations refer to both samples as well as to actual structures with stress concentrations. One suggested a procedure as to apply the obtained results to the case of random loading of a structure. The calculation examples show how the article makes use of the relations proposed.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Some mechanical structures and their components are stressed under fatigue such as for instance, pressure equipment, energetic generators, gas or steam turbines, heat engines, ships, aerospace, automotive, railway, and bridge structure.

Some are loaded by a successive ordered blocks of load (pressure equipment, energetic generators, steam turbine, etc.), others experience random loading during operation (heat engines, off shore structure, ships, aerospace, automotive, railway and bridge structures).

Various researchers (Schijve, 1972; Newman, 1997; Narayanaswami, 2001; Kim et al., 2006) have determined that the experimental fatigue lives for the specimens and parts of machines subjected to random amplitude loading can be below the fatigue lives predicted using constant amplitude test's results. But a higher fatigue life means a lower deterioration and viceversa.
For any structure it is of great importance to predict the deterioration under ordered block of load, but for others under random loading.

Sometimes the case of random external loading is approximated by block loading, estimated with a probabilistic analysis taking into account various models of material damage (Bagmutov and Savkin, 2007).

Some papers update the well known linear hypothesis by summing fatigue damage (Guriyev and Savkin, 1975; Troshchenko, 1975; Kogaev et al., 1985) or taking into account the effect of loading background for predicting the durability of machine parts exposed to random loading (Bagmutov and Savkin, 2007).
In this article the deterioration of structures loaded by successive ordered blocks of loads is analyzed. A procedure to apply these results to the case of random loading in suggested.

Fatigue stress can be determined by: – isothermal mechanical stresses (Figure 1), at lower or higher temperatures than creep temperature (Tc); – thermal stresses produced by cyclic temperature variation between Tmin and Tmax (Figure 2). Figure 1.
Isothermal cyclically variation of normal stresses. Figure 2.
Temperature cyclically variation with: Tmax<Tc (a); Tc<Tmax<Tu and Tmin<Tc (b); Tmin≥Tc and Tc<Tmax<Tu (c); Tu - failure temperature (similar with ultimate stress).

The cyclic thermal stress caused by preventing free deformation results in thermal stresses. For example, in the case of a bar one may write that in any point, the extreme stresses, in absolute value, are:

It often happens that σmax(T)<0 and σmin(T)<0 because of restraining the free deformation. At Tmax≥Tc (Figure 2(b) and (c)) one should also consider creep influence upon the effect of cyclic thermal stress.

The problem of failing mechanical structures has been under analysis in works (Miner, 1945; Marko and Strakey, 1954; Chaboche, 1981; Hwang and Han, 1986; Mischke, 1986; Morrow, 1986; Lemaitre and Chaboche, 1990; Jinescu, 1993; Hansen, 1999; Shang and Yao, 1999; Lagoda, 2001; Kaminski, 2002; Chen et al., 2006; Dattoma et al., 2006). The effects of fatigue under stress depends upon the behavior of the material under stress, stress rate, material sensitivity to cracking, mean stress, residual stresses, etc. (Jinescu, 2008a, b). Service stress is often random and variable in time. Using the specific energy concept (strain energy density) for description the fatigue processes is a good approach even for structures subjected to random heat-mechanical loading.
We shall further analyze the cases of cyclic stress at temperatures lower than creep temperature.

sec.title: PRESENT CALCULATION OF THE DETERIORATION OF CYCLICALLY STRESSED MECHANICAL STRUCTURES
sec.p: Deterioration means the irreversible reduction of the capacity of a material or structure from a certain point of view. For example, the reduction of the capacity of resistance, of deformation, etc. Various other definitions of the damage parameter are examined in the article (Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2009).
Kacianov (1958) introduced a scalar parameter of deterioration, D, with values between 0 and 1. Deterioration, a nondimensional variable, has the following property: (1)

Several relations have been proposed for the deterioration produced by the cyclic action of a single load. They contain reported values correlated with the process of deterioration and represent the macroscopic measure of the deterioration from the microscopic scale. Considering the existing proposal found in literature (Miner, 1945; Marko and Starkey, 1954; Chaboche, 1981; Hwang and Han, 1986; Mischke, 1986; Morrow, 1986; Lemaitre and Chaboche, 1990; Jinescu, 1993; Hansen, 1999; Shang and Yao, 1999; Lagoda, 2001; Kaminski, 2002; Chen et al., 2006; Dattoma et al., 2006), one finds that deterioration can be expressed in two ways, namely:

Deterioration expressed as a measure of a reduction of a certain mechanical or thermo mechanical characteristic (the elasticity module, resistance to failure, capable specific energy, etc.) that will be written as Dc, where subscript c shows that the deterioration refers to the reduction over time of a certain material characteristic; deterioration as a measure of the accumulation of the deformations or durations of mechanical and thermo mechanical stress is written as D.

In the relations proposed up to now for the calculation of the deterioration of the cyclically stressed materials and structures, makes no difference between the two deterioration concepts, D and Dc, presented above.

Owing to the relatively high differences between the calculations written on the basis of relations at positions 3 and the experimental results, the relations have been proposed based on the Palmgren–Miner relation (positions 4–8 from din Table 2).

Serensen and Kogayev have proposed for the deterioration produced by cyclic loading i, with ni cycles with the stress amplitude σa,i or strain amplitude ɛa,i, the following relation (Serensen et al., 1975): (2) where Fa,R is the so-called fatigue limit, expressed through stress (σa,R) or strain (ɛa,R), where R=σmin/σmax or R=ɛmin/ɛmax is the asymmetrical coefficient of the loading cycle; (Fa,ech)i – the equivalent amplitude of the parameter of fatigue (σa or εa); a – coefficient that allows taking into account the amplitude of stresses lower than the fatigue limit; proposed a = 0.5.

In the case of multi level stress loading, ((σa,1;σm,1); (σa,2;σm,2); (σa,i;σm,i)), according to Serensen et al. (1975), the total deterioration is calculated with the general relation: (3) where: (4) where fi=ni∑ini is the reported cyclic stress or strain frequency; (Fa,ech)max the maximum equivalent amplitude of the fatigue parameter.
For p = 1 one obtains the Palmgren–Miner relation of total deterioration: (5)

Serensen–Kogayev relation (4) leads to life cycles lower than the experimental ones. That places calculations on the safe side. The real Palmgren–Miner damage sum has a dispersion between Dreal = 0.01 and 10, because of nonlinearity of damage accumulation.

For loading with an extremely small number of cycles one proposed the relation (Kuroda, 2001): (6) where Dσ is the deterioration determined by the stress applied, Dn failure owing to cyclic loading, and Dc failure owing to crack propagation:
where εp, εu is the effective plastic and ultimate strain respectively; n, N number of effective and up to failure loading cycles, respectively; and β the material constant.

A similar idea is found in work (Tateishi et al., 2007) where the total deterioration is considered to be made up of a cyclic contribution (Dcyclic) and a ductile one (Dductile), (7) where;
εpD is the deterioration strain threshold in pure tension; Δɛmax is the maximum value of strain; εf the static fracture ductility; and Δɛp,max the maximum strain range.

For α = 0 which corresponds to the cyclic loading with a very high frequency and with δσm=1 and D = 1 relation (8) becomes relation Soderberg; if σu is replaced by σy one acquires the Goodman relation, while by replacing σu with σf' (fatigue strength coefficient) one obtains the Morrow relation (Tao and Xia, 2007).
The problem of accumulating the deterioration produced by fatigue loading is old but it is considered to be unsatisfactorily solved (Fatemi and Yang, 1998; Kaminski, 2002).

Many damage models have been proposed for different materials, ductile as well as quasi-brittle, but sometimes the damage models were written in a specific nonstandard thermodynamics (Desmorat et al., 2010) or based on energy equivalence (Lagoda, 2001; Grammenoudis et al., 2009a, b). Other damage models predict the effect of the material properties on the crack growth resistance (Ohata, et al., 2010) or the surface effect on damage evolution (Chen et al., 2010; Yang et al., 2010).

The calculated damage must fulfill the following condition,
where for the critical damage value DCr there are many recommendations in the design codes. If Palmgren–Miner relationship (5) is used, DCr = 1 in the ASME Code Section VIII (Division 3), Dcr=0.6(22e)0.75 in PD 5500 (e is the maximum of greatest thickness, or 22 mm), DCr = 0.3; 0.5 or 0.8 for pressure equipment (depending on the number of loading cycles) in EN–13445/3, but if Serensen–Kogayev relationship (3) is used, it is suggested DCr = 0.3 for being conservative (German Machine Design Code).

One further proposes new relations for calculating deterioration on the basis of the principle of critical energy (Jinescu, 1993, 2005), by considering the behavior law of the materials used in the mechanical structures and the Basquin relation (Basquin, 1910).

sec.title: PROPOSAL FOR A NEW CALCULATION MODEL FOR THE DETERIORATION OF ELEMENTS CYCLICALLY LOADED WITH ONE STRESS
sec.p: One considers nonlinear power law behavior of the material: (9) where Mσ, Mτ, and k are material constants.

The participation of the specific energy determined by the cyclic loading with the normal stress amplitude σa, according to the principle of critical energy (Jinescu, 1993, 1997, 2005), is written as: (10) where α=1/k. Participation P(σa)≡D(σa) is the deterioration produced by cyclic loading.

In Figure 3 (stress amplitude versus cycles to failure) the effective loading corresponds to point S(n;σa) where n is the effective number of loading cycles:
– at stress amplitude σa the number of cycles up to failure is Na;
– at loading with n cycles one gets to fatigue strength σ-1(n).
Figure 3.
Wöhler curve.
According to Basquin relation (Basquin, 1910) applied to zone II (Figure 3): (11) where the exponent m=m2 corresponds to zone II on the Wöhler curve.

Out of this relation one obtains:
where n∈[Ny;N0]. One obtains analogous relations for zones I and III (CD1) so that one can write the following expression for the deterioration produced through the loading of n cycles, with the amplitude of normal stress σa, of a standard sample: (12) where m is replaced by m1, m2, or m3 depending on whether we are referring to zone I, II, or III (curve CD1) of Wöhler curve (Figure 3).

Through particularizations from relation (21) one obtains some of the previously proposed expressions for D, namely (Table 2): Palmgren–Miner relation for (+1)/(α+1)mm=1 and Marko and Starkey relation for (+1)/(α+1)mm=p.

The sample fatigue strength (σ-1(N)) and the fatigue strength of any part of a structure (σ-1,s) are correlated through relations: (13) in the case of cyclic loading with normal stresses and: (14) under cyclic loading with shear stresses.

The deterioration produced under cyclic loading with normal stresses of a mechanical structure element is different from the standard sample and is written as: (15) or, expressed as a function of the number of loading cycles: (16) Analogously for fatigue loading with shear stresses, the structure deterioration is written as: (17) It follows that the same cyclic loading determines a higher deterioration in a machine part with stress concentrations than for a standard sample, which has not been explicitly taken into consideration up to now.

sec.title: DETERIORATION IN THE CASE OF EFFECT ACCUMULATION OF CYCLIC LOADING AND OTHER LOADS
Effect Accumulation Issue
sec.p: One analyzes the cases of accumulation or superposition of effects under temperatures that are lower than creep temperature.

As the behavior of the materials under load is generally nonlinear, the solution to the problem of superposition of loading effects cannot be made by using the Boltzmann principle, applicable only to materials with linear behavior.

The solution of these problems can be provided by using the principle of critical energy (Jinescu, 1993, 1997, 2005) which allows the accumulation of effects of loading of the same nature, but of different kinds, or of loading of a different nature in the general case of material with nonlinear behavior.

sec.title: Deterioration Produced by Cyclic Simultaneous Loading with Normal Stress and Shear Stress
sec.p:
With cyclic loading with normal stress, σ, and shear stress, τ, deterioration is produced by the amplitude of these stresses, σa and τa, respectively.
The left part of the well-known empirical relation (Gough and Pollard, 1935), a multiaxiality criterion was proposed (Carpinteri and Spagnoli, 2001; Spagnoli, 2001) as being the deterioration produced by the cyclic alternating symmetrical loading: (18) Recently Ninic (2006) has used relation (18) where he introduced a supplementary factor k=0.75…1.0, defining deterioration, through relation: (19) Relations (18) and (19) express the deterioration of a sample produced by alternating symmetrical loading with normal stresses (σa) and shear stresses (τa), at N>N0, in the zone of fatigue limit. That is the reason why there is no intervention of the number of loading cycles in this case.
Further down, one proposes a calculation relation based on the principle of critical energy. In the case of a sample under alternating symmetrical normal stresses, σa and shear stresses, τa, based upon the principle of critical energy (Jinescu, 1993, 2005) one may write that total failure is: (20)

By using Basquin's relation, the first term from relation (20) is replaced by a relation written as (12) and analogously one deals with the second term from relation (20), so that for a sample the total deterioration is: (21) where n(σa); n(τa) is the effective number of loading with stress amplitude σa, and τa, respectively while Na(σa); Na(τa) – number of loading cycles up to failure with the stress amplitude σa, and τa respectively.

For design elements or mechanical structures with stress concentrations, the total deterioration produced by the loading with stress amplitude σa and τa is obtained as a sum of the deteriorations produced by each of these stresses: (22)

After replacing the terms in the right part of the previous relation with expressions (16) and (17) one finds the total deterioration, of a design element or of a mechanical structure, written as: (23) which contains the influence of stress concentrations (Kσ and Kτ), the influence of the element dimension in comparison with that of the sample (ɛd), and the influence of the surface state of the element (γs).

sec.title: Deterioration Produced by Cyclic Loading with Several Successive Stress Blocks
sec.p:
The total deterioration in this case of ordered successive blocks of load (Figure 4) may be calculated, if the real damage sum is known because the dispersion of the real damage is so high (Dreal=0.01-10) that a reliable calculation of fatigue life is impossible without knowing the real value for the actual case. For example, the deterioration may be calculated on the basis of literature relations presented in Table 2 (positions 3–8), by summing up the deteriorations produced by each loading group (σi;ni). Figure 4.
Loading with several successive normal stress blocks.

In using the Palmgren–Miner (5) relation one found that failure occurred at total deterioration value which was either under one or over one. Miner (1945) showed that by using relation (5) failure occurred at D=0.61÷1.49. Later, depending on the number of loading cycles, the value of the stress applied at the beginning (high or small) one obtained a dispersion of the values of critical deterioration ranging between 0.2 and 3.0 (Jinescu, 1984), 0.24 and 7.5, and also 3.17 and 10.34 (Buch, 1976, 1988; Buzdugan and Blumenfeld, 1979).

In the case of simultaneous and/or successive loading with normal or shear stresses the total deterioration of a standard sample is obtained by summing up the individual stresses such that results are obtained by using the principle of critical energy (Jinescu, 1993, 2005): (24) or exactly written as: (25)
For any design element or mechanical structure, by analogy with relation (25) starting from relation (23), one obtains the following relation of total deterioration: (26)

sec.title: Deterioration Produced by Cyclic and Vibration Loading
sec.p: A cyclically loaded element or structure which is vibrating at the same time reaches the critical state before a structure loaded only cyclically under the same conditions. The effective deterioration is computed with the general relation (26) to which one adds sub-unitary function which depends on the ratio of the pulsation ω of the vibration reported to the own fundamental pulsation ωCr: (27)

Consequently, the total deterioration of an element which is cyclically loaded and vibrates with pulsation ω is: (28) where the value of ωCr depends on the vibration type (longitudinal, torsion, or bending). Sometimes (Jinescu, 2005) f(ωωcr)=(ωωcr)2.

sec.title: Deterioration Produced by Loading with Several Cyclic Stresses in a Corrosive Environment
sec.p:
When loading cyclically a crackless steel sample, in a corroding environment, the number of cycles up to failure diminishes as compared to vacuum loading. Figure 5 shows the Wöhler curves (σmax-N) for steel ISO 5832-9 under air and solution 0.9% NaCl up 37°C loading, respectively. Figure 5.
Wöhler curve (σmax-N) for the steel ISO 5832-9: 1 – in air; 2 – in 0.9%NaCl solution, at 37°C. (adapted from Giordani et al. (2004)).
The deterioration produced by cyclic loading in a corrosive environment can be determined by accumulating the effects of the two actions according to the principle of critical energy (Jinescu, 2005).

In the uniform corrosion of a material, the reduction of thickness (Amirat et al., 2006): (29) is proportional to a constant of the corrosion process kz and with the time of corrosion, t, at a certain power c.

In the case of generalized corrosion, deterioration of a structure of initial thickness δ may be written as: (30) where t is the time of contact with the corroding substance while tt - duration until complete corrosion throughout the whole structure wall thickness undergoing corrosion. The consequences of the changes on surface may be taken into account by the value of surface quality coefficient, γs.

The total deterioration represents the linear accumulation of the deteriorations produced by the cyclic loading and corrosion. In the case of a cyclic loading of a crackless material under normal stress in a corroding environment, out of relations (12) and (30) one obtains the total deterioration of a standard sample, as a sum of dimensionless power-dependent parameters: (31) to be verified by experiments.

A cracked material under cyclic loading in a corroding environment deteriorates more quickly, with a larger crack, which has been demonstrated for defects of 0.1–0.7 mm in samples made of aircraft aluminum alloys (DuQuesnay et al., 2003).

By considering the time evolution of the crack/defect (Jinescu, 2005) the total deterioration is written as: (32) where the last term in the right-hand part represents the deterioration produced only by the crack a(t). The crack critical dimension acr is independent of the corrosive effect.

The rate of the crack under the corrosive environment depends on its aggressiveness (Trusculescu et al., 2003). If the crack evolution expressed through the derivative da/dn depends on the corrosive environment then relation (32) becomes: (33) where a(t)cs is the effective length of the crack after corroding duration t, calculated by considering the dependence of speed da/dn on the action of the corrosive environment. In other words:
In the case of loading with several blocks of cyclic normal stresses of a mechanical structure the total deterioration is written as follows for:

sec.title: Cracked materials
sec.p: In the case of a sample one replaces Kσɛd·γs=1.
In case there appears cyclic loading with shear stresses, then in relations (34) and (35) one adds the deterioration caused by them, which is calculated with similar relations by replacing σ with τ.

sec.title: DETERIORATION PRODUCED BY RANDOM LOADING
sec.p:
The results obtained for ordered block loading may be applied to random loading by using, for example, the root mean square (RMS) method (Kim et al., 2006). One analyzes the loading history of the structure and calculates:
– The RMS maximum stress: (36)
– The RMS minimum stress: (37) where σmax,i and σmin,i the maximum and minimum stresses derived from random stress history; m is the total number of σmax,i or σmin,i values;
– The RMS normal stress amplitude and mean stress: (38)
– The RMS shear stress amplitude and mean shear stress: (39) where maximum and minimum RMS shear stresses are calculated with relation (36) and (37) by replacing σ with τ.
The values of σa,rms and σm,rms as well for τa,rms and τm,rms one introduces the relationships deduced for the deterioration in this article.
In this way the relationships established in the part 4 of the article may applied to the random loaded structures.

sec.title: NUMERICAL EXAMPLES
sec.p:
(a) Let us calculate the deterioration produced in a mechanical structure cyclically loaded with two blocks of normal stresses and a block of shear stress (Table 3). Table 3.
Loading characteristics.

Shear stresses τmax – 260

Stress amplitude σa 300 175 –
τa – – 130
Mean stress σm 0 175 –
τm – – 130
Number of loading cycles to failure Na(σa) 1.45×106 0.92×106 –
Na(τa) – – 1.21×106
The residual stress in the most dangerous section of the structure is σres=166 MPa.
The critical deterioration results by considering the residual stress (Jinescu, 2005, 2008b):
Since the maximum stresses satisfy conditions σ-1<σmax<σy and τ-1<τmax<τy the loading pertain to domain II (Figure 3).
The total deterioration is calculated with relation (26) written as
After replacement one obtains,
Since Dt,s(n)>Dcr loading is dangerous.

(b) One takes into consideration the same structure loaded only with normal stress blocks (Table 3), but with a crack of characteristic dimension a(n)=3 mm in the dangerous section. The crack critical dimension acr=25 mm.
In this case, the contributions of the crack to the deterioration according to relation (32) is:
The total deterioration results from summing up the deterioration produced by cyclic loading and cracking:
Since Dt(n;a)<Dcr≡0.894 the loading is not dangerous.

(c) If one adds a corroding action resulting in deterioration to the loading under point (b):
then the total deterioration is:
Since Dt(n;a;tcs)>Dcr loading is dangerous.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Here are the results of the analysis of deterioration relations found in literature for fatigue loading: some refer to the reduction of a certain mechanical characteristic, while the others refer to the accumulation of strains or loading cycles. The empirical Palmgren–Miner relation is still used in design despite its shortcomings; it does not take into consideration the material behavior, the loading background, as well as the influence of load sequences.

The article proposes calculation relations based on the principle of critical energy which takes into consideration the elements overlooked (Tables 1 and 2) in existing relations or neglected (material behavior, influence of corrosion, and vibrations).

The advantage of the relations proposed derives from the application of the principle of critical energy based on which one may sum up the terms, namely the deterioration caused by loading of the same or various nature (mechanical, chemical, etc.).
One suggested to use the deduced relations for the case of random loading, by calculation of the maximum and minimum stresses on the basis of root mean square (RMS) method.

The numerical examples show how one can use the new relations proposed for the calculation of a structure deterioration produced by the cyclic loading with normal and shear stresses in the case of crackless as well as in the case of a crack, in a corroding environment.
NOMENCLATURE
D; Ds Deterioration; Structure deterioration
Dcr Critical deterioration
E(t) Modulus of elasticity (Young) at temperature T
Kσ; Kτ The theoretical stress concentration factors (notch factor) of normal; Shear stress
N Number of cycles to failure at given stress amplitude
N0 Number of cycles at the knee point
Ny The N value corresponding the yield stress
T Temperature
Tc Creep temperature
Tmax; Tmin Maximum, Minimum temperature
T0 Environmental temperature
Δδcs Thickness reduction due to corrosion
a(t) Crack characteristic length at time t
acr Critical value of the crack length
k Strain exponent
n Number of loading cycles
t,tcs Time, Time of total corrosion
α(t) Coefficient of longitudinal thermal expansion at temperature T
γ Shear strain
γs Surface quality coefficient
ε Strain
ɛd Dimensional coefficient
σ Normal stress
σa;σm Normal stress amplitude; Mean normal stress
σmax;σmin Maximum stress; Minimum stress
σmax,rms;σmin,rms The root mean square method maximum; Minimum stress
σres Residual stress
σu;τu Ultimate stress for normal; Shear stress
σy;τy Normal; Shear yield stress
σ-1;τ-1 Fatigue (endurance) limit for normal; Shear stress loading
σ-1(N);τ-1(N) Fatigue strength under the alternating symmetrical loading with N cycles in the case of normal stress; shear stress loading
σ-1,s Fatigue strength of any part of a structure
τ Shear stress
ω Pulsation of the vibration
ωcr Critical value of ω (the own fundamental vibration)
